skills.title: Evaluating sine
skills.description: We're going to get fluent with the values of the sine function at multiples of `pi/6` and `pi/4`.

mentalRepresentations.title: The unit circle
mentalRepresentations.bodyMarkdown:
Hold in your head the unit circle of radius `1` centered at the origin, like this.

![The unit circle](/assets/images/unit_circle.svg)

As you think about a question, first pinpoint exactly where the point created by the angle is on the circumference of the unit circle.  The `y` coordinate of that point is the value of the sine function at the given angle.

skills.title: Evaluating cosine
skills.description: We're going to get fluent with the values of the cosine function at multiples of `pi/6` and `pi/4`.

mentalRepresentations.title: The unit circle
mentalRepresentations.bodyMarkdown:
Hold in your head the unit circle of radius `1` centered at the origin, like this.

![The unit circle](/assets/images/unit_circle.svg)

As you think about a question, first pinpoint exactly where the point created by the angle is on the circumference of the unit circle.  The `x` coordinate of that point is the value of the cosine function at the given angle.

skills.title: Evaluating tangent
skills.description: We're going to get fluent with the values of the tangent function at multiples of `pi/6` and `pi/4`.

mentalRepresentations.title: Recalling sine and cosine
mentalRepresentations.bodyMarkdown:
The tangent function is defined to be `(sin A)/(cos A)` for some angle A.  So you need to fluently evaluate the sine and cosine function.

If you're struggling, do some deliberate practice of those skills.

mentalRepresentations.title: Imagining the gradient of the line
mentalRepresentations.bodyMarkdown:
The tangent function of an angle is also the gradient of the line created by that angle with the horizontal.

So picture the shape of the line created by the angle and ask yourself what its gradient must be.

For example, we can tell instantly that the line y = x has a gradient of 1, so `tan pi/4 = 1`.

skills.title: Compound angle identity for sine
skills.description: We can evaluate more complicated sine functions using the identity `sin(A +- B) \equiv sin A cos B +- cos A sin B`

skills.title: Adding unlike fractions
skills.description: Unlike fractions have different denominators.  We can sum two unlike fractions by converting them to like fractions.

skills.title: Finding the least common denominator
skills.description: Finding the least common denominator of two fractions is the first step in combining unlike fractions.

mentalRepresentations.title: Definition
mentalRepresentations.bodyMarkdown: The least common denominator of a set of fractions is the least common multiple of their denominiators.  For example, the least common multiple of `3`, `6` and `9` is `18`, and so the least common _divisor_ of `1/3`, `5/6` and `7/9` is also `18`.

mentalRepresentations.title: If the denominators have no common factor
mentalRepresentations.bodyMarkdown: If the denominators have no common factor, the least common divisor is their product.  For example, the least common divisor of `1/2`, `2/3` and `5/7` is 42, the product of `2`, `3` and `7`.

mentalRepresentations.title: If the greatest denominator is a multiple of all the other denominators
mentalRepresentations.bodyMarkdown: If the greatest denominator is a multiple of _all_ the other denominators, then the least common denominator must be the greatest denominator.  For example, the least common denominator of `1/2`, `2/3` and `5/12` is the greatest denominator, 12.

mentalRepresentations.title: List the multiples of the greatest denominator if unsure
mentalRepresentations.bodyMarkdown: List the multiples of the greatest denominator in ascending order, then find the least multiple divisible by _all_ the other denominators.  For example, to find the least common divisor of `1/2`, `2/5`, `11/12` and `13/15`, list the multiples of `15`, which are `15, 30, 45, 60, 75, ...`, and note that `60` is the least multiple divisible by `2`, `5`, and `12`.  Hence, `60` is the least common divisor.

questions.text: Find the least common denominator of `1/3`, `5/6` and `7/9`.
Find the least common denominator of `1/2`, `2/3` and `5/7`.
Find the least common denominator of `1/2`, `2/5`, `11/12` and `13/15`.
Find the least common denominator of `1/2` and `2/3`.
Find the least common denominator of `1/3` and `4/5`.
Find the least common denominator of `1/2`, `4/3` and `2/5`.
Find the least common denominator of `1/3` and `5/6`.
Find the least common denominator of `7/8` and `1/4`.
Find the least common denominator of `3/5`, `1/3` and `8/15`.
Find the least common denominator of `5/8` and `7/12`.
Find the least common denominator of `3/4`, `1/6` and `7/9`.
Find the least common denominator of `5/6`, `7/9` and `11/15`.
